description: This course provides an introduction to the fundamental concepts of Materials Science through an examination of the structure, property, performance relationship for synthetic and biologic structural materials with a focus on surgical implants and medical devices. Consideration is given to issues of biocompatibility, degradation of materials by the biologic systems, and biologic response to artificial materials. Particular attention will be given to the materials of total hip and knee prostheses and their relationship to the long term outcomes in hip and knee arthroplasty.
name: STRUCTURAL MATERIALS

values.comments:
This course provides an introduction to the fundamental concepts of materials
science through an examination of the structure, property, and performance relationship
for synthetic and biologic structural materials with a focus on surgical implants and
medical devices. Consideration is given to issues of biocompatibility, degradation of
materials by the biologic systems, and biologic response to artificial materials. Particular
attention is given to the materials of total hip and knee prostheses and their relationship to
the long-term outcomes in hip and knee arthroplasty.
Students for the most part felt that they “gained a lot” from taking this course. A
lot of material was covered, but students felt that it was “extremely useful” knowledge
for all engineers.
Students were generally satisfied with Professor Winey. They also raved about
their teaching assistant Skyler Silverman, claiming that he “beats any TA.”
Though this class covered a lot of material, students felt that it was manageable.
Daily quizzes meant that students had to stay on top of the course. One student
recommended the course to all engineer majors. The prerequisites for this course are
knowledge of basic calculus and chemistry.
